Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Multi-Length Scale Design of Earthquake Damage-Resistant and Self-Sensing Cementitious Composites

POR.DRECONTENT:
Catastrophic structural failures are usually caused by attacks from natural disasters, such as tornados, earthquakes, etc. In general, structures are designed to sustain external excitations stronger than the most severe cases in record; however, internal structural imperfections, such as cracks and corrosions may degrade structure’s dynamic performance and they are usually hard to be detected at early stage. Therefore, there is a dire need for in-situ monitoring system installed to instantaneously provide information regarding to local structural behavior. Among many applications, a carbon nanotube reinforced polymeric thin film has been developed to detect any local strain changes or pH changes in order to achieve 2-dimensional structural health monitoring (SHM). However, it is important to study several essential mechanical properties of the nanocomposite before real-time application.

One of the most critical properties is the fracture behavior of the thin film. In order to minimize possible interferences brought by experimental instruments, a non-contact method using high resolution video camera capturing the entire crack propagation procedure is developed. In collaboration with National Taiwan University (NTU) and National Center for Research on Earthquake Engineering (NCREE)  an shaking table test with a 3-floor high steel structure has been conducted, and the entire structural dynamic has been captured using a commercial high-definition video camera. A matlab algorithm has been developed to process the video data and to extract displacement data, which is later compared with collected displacement data from other installed instruments (i.e., LVDT data). The analytical results shows excellent overlapping of data collected via the video camera and that from the LVDTs, demonstrating the validity of the non-contact method and the developed algorithm (Shown in Figure 1). The experimental results suggest that the adoption of this video camera method to capture crack propagation is feasible, and the developed algorithm can be applied for fractural property analysis using captured video data.

A series of experiments on fractural behavior has been conducted afterwards by using the same non-contact method back in the States. As a result, the entire crack propagation procedure is successfully extracted from the video data collected, and several important fractural properties have been thus identified and quantified. The experimental results are significant in terms of contribution to a more integrated study of the carbon nanotube thin film’s mechanical performance. By utilizing its displacement/strain information, the fracture behavior of the thin film can be identified for further improvement of the material, such that its novelty can be further maintained under severe mechanical distortion.  In addition, the results have provided feasible experimental techniques for studying fracture behavior of similar nanocomposites. Eventually, this result has effectively moved forward on developing novel damage sensors, which are expected to be applied on structures in the future to prevent severe structural failures.

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2011
Modified by: Yingjun Zhao

Among many applications, a carbon nanotube reinforced polymeric thin film has been developed to detect any local strain changes or pH changes in order to achieve 2-dimensional structural health monitoring (SHM).
